importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The starting point of the Hamas-led attack that led to the hostage crisis and the beginning of the broader conflict.
The estimated date of death of Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage, who was believed to have been killed in captivity.
The date the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed, setting a timeline for the return of hostages.
The day the remains of two deceased hostages were returned to Israel, marking a key development in the ceasefire implementation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Hamas was required under the agreement to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours, a deadline that has been widely criticized as unattainable due to the challenging conditions in Gaza.

keyTakeAways: Arye Zalmanovich, 85, was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas on October 7, 2023, and died in captivity on November 17, 2023. He was from Kibbutz Nir Oz and was one of the community's founders.
Tamir Adar, 38, died defending Kibbutz Nir Oz on October 7, 2023, and his body was taken to Gaza. His remains were returned to Israel in October 2025.
The two deceased hostages' remains were transferred to Israel for identification and forensic investigation at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine.
The return of these bodies is part of a larger effort under the Trump administration's ceasefire agreement, which requires Hamas to return 28 hostages (living and deceased).
Hamas has said it requires significant effort and special equipment to recover bodies in Gaza, and one previously returned body was misidentified, raising concerns about accountability and accuracy.
US Vice President JD Vance emphasized that returning the bodies is a priority but stressed it will not happen overnight, especially given the rubble and unknown locations of some victims.
The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have called for public sensitivity and official identification before informing families.
The ceasefire deal remains fragile, with both Israel and Hamas accusing each other of violations, including attacks that killed Israeli soldiers and Hamas-led assaults.

namedEntities.name: Arye Zalmanovich
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli hostage taken on October 7, 2023, from Kibbutz Nir Oz; the oldest hostage held by Hamas; died in captivity at age 85 on November 17, 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the extreme age and vulnerability of hostages, highlighting the human cost of the conflict and the emotional toll on families.

namedEntities.name: Tamir Adar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli from Kibbutz Nir Oz who died defending his community on October 7, 2023, and whose body was taken to Gaza. His remains were returned to Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He symbolizes the loss of young lives and the tragic military deaths that occurred during the initial Hamas attack.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The militant group responsible for the October 7, 2023, attack on Israel and the subsequent hostage crisis; accused of holding Israeli hostages and burying bodies in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the conflict, responsible for the abduction and killing of hostages, and is required under the ceasefire to return deceased victims.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military of Israel involved in the response to Hamas, including operations to recover bodies and enforce the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is directly involved in monitoring the return of hostages, identifying bodies, and asserting that Hamas must comply with the ceasefire terms.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The US government that brokered the ceasefire deal and continues to push for the return of hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It established the initial framework for hostage return, including timelines and expectations, and has become a key external actor in the conflict's resolution.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Vice President who visited Israel and addressed concerns about the return of deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly affirmed the importance of returning bodies to families, emphasizing that it is difficult but essential, and downplayed timelines for full compliance.

namedEntities.name: Kibbutz Nir Oz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A kibbutz in southern Israel where both Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar were from and where the initial Hamas attack began.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the origin point of both victims, showing the localized impact of the attack and the communityâ€™s deep connection to the events.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution that received the remains for identification and investigation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It plays a critical role in verifying the identities of the deceased and investigating causes of death.

namedEntities.name: Ceasefire deal (signed October 9, 2025)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An agreement between Israel and Hamas, brokered by the US, requiring Hamas to return all living and deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It sets the legal and moral framework for the return of hostages, including the deceased, and remains central to the current diplomatic situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The oldest hostage taken by Hamas on October 7, 2023, Arye Zalmanovich, aged 85, was among the two deceased bodies returned to Israel on October 21, 2025, following the implementation of the US-proposed ceasefire deal. The bodies of Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar, a 38-year-old who died defending his kibbutz, were transferred to Israel for identification and investigation. The return of these remains is part of a broader effort under the ceasefire agreement, which requires Hamas to return 28 hostages within 72 hours. However, Hamas has stated it requires significant resources to recover bodies in Gaza, and one previously returned body was misidentified, raising concerns about accuracy. The Israeli military and US officials, including Vice President JD Vance, have stressed the importance of returning the bodies to families, emphasizing that the process is difficult and will not happen overnight. The event reflects the fragile state of the ceasefire, with both sides accusing each other of violations, and underscores the emotional and logistical challenges of recovering human remains in war-torn Gaza.
title: Oldest hostage taken on October 7 among two deceased returned to Israel Tuesday
